It follows that White, having the first move, is, so to speak, always morally justified in attacking, whilst Black should assume the defensive.
The first question which arises in our mind is: Which file will Black be able to utilise for his Rooks?
That is the object of Black's waiting move.
The Rook can win against a minor piece in exceptional cases only.
When the pawns are united, one should observe this rule: if they are attacked, they should, if possible, move to squares of the colour of the opposing Bishop.
The stronger side will evidently try to queen the pawn.
But even without this advantage, the weakness of doubled pawns usually entails the loss of the game.
